awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Roles of Inter-limb Jets and Body Angles in Metachronal Paddling
awd_abstract_narration:
Commercial underwater drones typically rely on a single propeller element. If this element were to fail, then the drone would be lost.  In contrast, the existence of multiple propulsion elements would permit continued use upon failure of a single propeller.  Natural aquatic organisms illustrate a unique opportunity to use multiple propulsion elements to generate small-scale jets.  Krill, shrimp, and crayfish, all use several pairs of limbs in highly coordinated motion to swim. The animal rhythmically oscillates its limbs from the tail-to-head at low velocity, with the timing of each pair delayed relative to its neighbors.  Nature?s design uses much less energy than our engineered underwater drones. Mechanical elements, such as gears and timing belts, could be used to cost effectively mimic nature?s design.  However, the underlying fluid dynamics of this metachronal (sequential) paddling is not well-understood. A limited number of studies have suggested limb morphology, the precision timing of the paddling sequence, and the generation of jets in the wake of the organism all contribute to this unique propulsion mechanism.  This research project examines how coordination of adjacent limbs interact with the flow past the body to generate propulsive jets in the wake. Uncovering the underlying fluid dynamic principles of metachronal paddling will enable scalability to engineered devices, allowing for efficient design of miniaturized, bio-inspired autonomous underwater drones. 

This research project examines how the coordinated motion of multiple oscillating paddles merge with large-scale flow past a submerged object to generate propulsive forces.  A combination of experiments with both live animals and robotic models will be used. Tomographic particle image velocimetry measurements of free-swimming aquatic organisms will be used to validate flow fields predicted by physical models. Self-propelled metachronal swimming robots will be used to examine the flow for individual and collective motion of the robots. Mechanical performance with respect to body angles, swimming speeds, and neighbor distances in individual and small groups of metachronal paddling robots will be examined. A primary project outcome will be the fluid dynamics mechanism by which aquatic organisms achieve large body speeds by paddling individual limbs at low velocity. The outcomes of this research will enable engineers to design and coordinate the motion of multiple propellers on engineered devices.  In addition, the research project trains undergraduate and graduate students to conduct interdisciplinary research in bioengineering.  Existing mechanisms at both institutions (NSF-funded Oklahoma Louis-Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation and Georgia Tech FOCUS program) are being used to recruit under-represented students for the project, and the researchers are participating in outreach activities to high school students and their teachers.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Numerous aquatic animals ranging in size from 10 microns to 10 cm, such as krill, crayfish and shrimp, swim via sequential rowing of closely spaced appendages or limbs. Each appendage moves with a delay relative to its immediate neighbor, starting from the back-most appendage and progressing to the appendage in front of the animal. The rhythmic and coordinated paddling of appendages results in the formation of a metachronal wave that is in the direction of the animal motion. Metachronal swimming is used for diverse purposes in these animals, such as forward motion, vertical migration, hovering, escaping (sprinting), and ambush predation. Despite the widespread natural prevalence of this swimming strategy, little is known about the physical principles underlying the success of metachronal paddling. This technique is also ripe for adaptation by engineers designing underwater drones, as the possibilities of being able to use the same mechanism for smaller and larger vehicles alike are appealing. From experimental studies on metachronal paddling robots, we find that constructive interactions of the vortices (flow reversal regions) produced by neighboring paddles can enable larger force production. The direction of the flow generated by the swimming limbs can be modified from horizontal to vertical by changing the time delay between neighboring appendages. Further, animals that use metachronal swimming show a narrow variation of the spacing between appendages relative to appendage length. Experiments on self-propelling robots reveal that the biological range is best suited for achieving greater swimming speed, as increasing the spacing between appendages weakens the interactions between the flows generated by neighboring appendages. Animals that primarily use metachronal rowing for predation or escaping, such as the mantis shrimp, use a modified version of this strategy in which their swimming limbs move in a metachronal rhythm for the power generating part of the stroke, but execute the return stroke in a nearly synchronous manner. Our studies show that this hybrid form of metachronal rowing allows for the swimming limbs to increase the range of their excursion (stroke amplitude) while avoiding collision of neighboring appendages. Collectively, these studies point to the numerous ways in which different animals have adapted the use of the basic metachronal rowing strategy for succeeding in feeding, migration, and avoiding predators. This award has provided opportunities for several graduate and undergraduate students to receive cross-disciplinary training in techniques used in engineering design and manufacturing, fluid mechanics, biomechanics, and robotics. Students in different majors (engineering, biology, physics) were trained to work collaboratively in this project and present their work at several major scientific meetings. Two capstone design teams (seniors) were mentored to design and build bio-inspired underwater drones. Through collaboration with the OSU Teach program at Oklahoma State University, Pre-service Science Teachers (PSTs) were trained in conducting hypothesis-driven research and developing inquiry-based high school science lesson plans. Hands-on activities were developed for high school students and teachers visiting Oklahoma State University research facilities. These activities provided the students and teachers a first-hand opportunity to experience how engineering approaches can be used to study biological questions and in biologically inspired design of devices.


Last Modified: 04/07/2023
Modified by: Arvind Santhanakrishnan
